sections.code:
KOS: VITAL ARRIVAL INFO
Back to top

You are on the island of Kos in Greece .

Upon arrival on the beach, you need to walk to the Kos Police Station near the port to receive a ticket.

The ticket tells you when it is your turn to register (see Registration Process Below). Do NOT lose your ticket.

Tickets are distributed ONLY between midnight and 05:00. If you arrive after 05:00, you will need to go the next day between midnight and 05:00 to receive your ticket.

Important!

  • Keep your travel documents and registration information on you at all times.
  • STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

In Case of Family Separation

If you have been separated from a family member, contact the Red Cross where you are.

  • Greek Restoring Family Links Hotline: 210 524 2194

You may also contact the Red Cross at the final destination country.

Austria +43 15 890 0126
Croatia +385 14 655 814
Germany + 49 (0) 89 680 773 111
Greece +30 210 524 2194
FYR Macedonia +389 23 114 355
Serbia + 381 (0) 11 26 23 970


If you are interested in declaring asylum in Greece:

DECLARING ASYLUM IN GREECE

There are a number of ways you can keep yourself or your families safe. Please see below for more information on tips to keep yourselves safe.

PARENTS AND FAMILIES

CHILDREN TRAVELING ALONE

COLD CLIMATES

Upon arrival on the beach, you need to walk to the Kos Police Station near the port to receive a ticket.

The ticket tells you when it is your turn to register (see Registration Process Below). Do NOT lose your ticket.

Tickets are distributed ONLY between midnight and 05:00. If you arrive after 05:00, you will need to go the next day between midnight and 05:00 to receive your ticket.
Important!

STAY TOGETHER! All family members should remain together at all times. It is advised that children have the names of family members and a phone number in their clothing in case they are separated.

sections.code:
NEWS
Back to top

Idomeni: Things to Know About the Situation at the Border

The entire border is patrolled by Macedonian (FYROM) police, not just at Idomeni FYROM Police on the other side of the border are authorised to use physical force and tear gas Many refugees describe very difficult and dangerous conditions when they take the journey (alone and with unknown people) into the Balkans​. Three people drowned ... Read more

EU and Turkey Deal: How Will it Affect Refugees in Europe?

On Thursday March 17 the European Union and Turkey could make deal that will impact on refugees currently in Greece and people still waiting to cross from Turkey to Greece by sea or by land. The re-opening of the Balkan Route is not on the agenda for discussion. Changes to the Balkan Route may be ... Read more

Rumours: Resettlement in Canada, Ferry Tickets & the ‘Kharti’

sections.code:
REGISTRATION: POLICE STATION
Back to top

How to Register

  • Registration takes place in two steps:
    • First, you have to register at the police station (with the Hellenic Coast Guards, the Police and Frontex) where you will receive a ticket with the registration date and a number. Frontex is open from midnight until 05:00. If you arrive after Frontex is closed, you must go the following night at midnight to get your number.
    • The second step takes place the next day. You must return to the police station at 09:00, 12:00 and 15:00. to check if your number has been called.
    • When it has, you must present the ticket with your number. The police will process your registration document. This document allows Syrians to stay in Greece for up to six months and non-Syrians for up to one month.
  • Once you have your document, you can go to the Blue Star ferry kiosk to purchase a ferry ticket to Athens.

For additional information about the police registration document, registration procedures, rights and obligations in Greece, or access to asylum procedures, please approach the UNHCR (wearing blue vests) at the police station during registration hours. UNHCR conducts group and individual information sessions during the registration process, and in several hotels on an as-needed basis.

Registration Point Location

  • Registration is at the Kos Police Station near the port.

If you are interested in declaring asylum in Greece:

DECLARING ASYLUM IN GREECE
sections.name: REGISTRATION:  POLICE STATION
sections.text:
REGISTRATION:  POLICE STATION
Back to top



How to Register

Registration takes place in two steps:
	
First, you have to register at the police station (with the Hellenic Coast Guards, the Police and Frontex) where you will receive a ticket with the registration date and a number. Frontex is open from midnight until 05:00. If you arrive after Frontex is closed, you must go the following night at midnight to get your number. 
The second step takes place the next day. You must return to the police station at 09:00, 12:00 and 15:00. to check if your number has been called.
When it has, you must present the ticket with your number. The police will process your registration document. This document allows Syrians to stay in Greece for up to six months and non-Syrians for up to one month.


Once you have your document, you can go to the Blue Star ferry kiosk to purchase a ferry ticket to Athens.

For additional information about the police registration document, registration procedures, rights and obligations in Greece, or access to asylum procedures, please approach the UNHCR (wearing blue vests) at the police station during registration hours. UNHCR conducts group and individual information sessions during the registration process, and in several hotels on an as-needed basis.
Registration Point Location

Registration is at the Kos Police Station near the port.  


If you are interested in declaring asylum in Greece:
DECLARING ASYLUM IN GREECE

sections.code:
SERVICES
Back to top

Map of Service Locations

UNHCR

  • Information regarding the asylum process, access to protection services, and legal aid in Greece.
  • Group and individual counseling sessions.
  • Transportation for new arrivals to Frontex.
  • Accommodation sites, including Oscar Hotel.
  • Specialized protection services for vulnerable cases.
  • Assists persons of concern to access the registration process.
  • Provides protective, friendly, and safe accommodation service for unaccompanied refugee children before they are transferred to Athens.
  • Provides support for shipwreck survivors.
  • Has a 24/7 hotline number (Tel: +30 6944585694 ), email address ( GREATKOS@UNHCR.ORG ), and suggestion box at the tent camp for refugees and other persons of concern who wish to submit feedback and complaints.

Mercy Corps

  • Manages the Oscar Hotel, including:
    • accommodation for refugees with a voucher,
    • breakfast and lunch service,
    • clothing distribution for families and vulnerable cases.
  • Provides dinner at Boomerang restaurant for Oscar Hotel guests.
  • Provides transportation from the Oscar Hotel to Frontex at 11:30 p.m. daily.

MSF

  • Tent accommodation at the archaeological site.
  • Free medical clinic next to the tent camp (09:00 - 17:00 daily).
  • Psychological services at clinic.

Samaritan's Purse

  • Non-food items, including blankets, clothing, and hygiene kits at the Oscar Hotel and other shelters.
  • Heating station at the port.

Save the Children

  • Psycho-social support through recreational activities for children at the Oscar Hotel (Monday - Saturday from 11:00 - 18:00).
  • Works with Arsis to identify unaccompanied and separated children and refer them to the appropriate services.

WAHA

  • Medical assistance at the port from 21:00 - 02:00 daily and at the Oscar Hotel from 13:00 - 15:00 daily.

Flying Help

  • Conducts night patrol.
  • Transportation for new arrivals to Frontex.
  • Clothing, blankets, and snacks at the port.

Kos Kindness

  • Clothing, toiletries, and baby food at the Oscar Hotel.

koskindness@outlook.com

Kos Refugees Need Your Help

  • Breakfast (07:00 - 08:00) and lunch (14:00) for single men at Kyttaro Club.
  • Lunch at the Oscar Hotel.
  • Tea, television, and games for single men at Kyttaro Club (14:00 - 23:00 daily)

Kos Solidarity

  • Transportation for new arrivals to Frontex.
  • Clothing, blankets, and snacks at the port for new arrivals and those departing for Athens.
  • Breakfast at 09:00 and dinner at 17:00 next to the police station.
  • Conducts night patrol.

Tel: 69460 85065, 22420 28523

METAction

  • Provides interpreters for the UNHCR and Greek authorities.

Praksis

  • Provides shelter for unaccompanied minors, including the provision of food, NFIs, legal and psychosocial support, recreational activities, routine medical examinations, and any necessary medications.
  • Escorts unaccompanied minors to and from the police station and clinic.
  • Provides transportation for unaccompanied minors from Kos to Athens.

Greek Council for Refugees

  • Legal support and legal representation services.

Tel: 21038 00990 (Athens, Greece)

sections.code:
MEDICAL
Back to top

MSF Clinic

  • MSF has a free medical clinic in the Archeological Park behind the police station.

CLINIC LOCATION

WAHA Clinics

  • WAHA provides free medical services:
    • At the Oscar Hotel from 13:00 - 15:00 daily and
    • At a mobile clinic at the port from 21:00 - 02:00 nightly.

General Hospital of Kos , 34 Ippokratous Str.

HOSPITAL LOCATION
